substitution.copyText: Ham. Hear you Sir, | I lov'd you ever, but it is not matter, | Let Hercules himself do what he may | The Cat will mew, a Dog will have his day.
substitution.amendedText: Ham. Hear you Sir,-- | I lov'd you ever; but it is not matter.-- | Let Hercules himself do what he may, | The Cat will mew; a Dog will have his day.

substitution.copyText: King. I pray thee good Horatio wait upon him.
substitution.amendedText: King. I pray you, good Horatio wait upon him.

substitution.copyText: Good Gertrard set some watch over you son, | This Grave shall have a living monument, | " An hour of quiet thereby shall we see, | " Till then in patience our proceeding be.
substitution.amendedText: Good Gertrud, set some watch over you son, | This Grave shall have a living monument,
Enter Hamlet and Horatio meeting Ostrick

substitution.copyText: Ham. So much for this Sir. Now shall you see the other: | You do remember all the circumstance. Hora. Remember it my Lord? Ham. Sir in my heart there was a kind of fighting | That would not let me sleep, " methought I lay | " Worse than the mutines in the Bilboes, rashly, " And prais'd be rashness for it; let us know, | Our indiscretion sometime serves us well | When our deep plots do fall, and that should learn us, | There's a divinity that shapes our ends, | Rough hew them how we will.
substitution.amendedText: Ham. So much for this Sir. Now shall you see the other: | You do remember all the circumstance? Hora. Remember it my Lord? Ham. Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting, | That would not let me sleep; | and that should learn us, | There's a divinity that shapes our ends, | Rough hew them how we will.

substitution.copyText: My Sea-gown wrapt about me, in the dark | I grop'd to find out them, had my desire, | Reach'd their packet, and in fine withdrew | To mine own room again, making so bold | (My fears forgetting manners) to unfold | Their grand Commission; where I found, Horatio, | An exact command, | " Larded with many several sorts of reasons, | " Importing Denmarks health, and Englands too, | " With hoe such Bugs and Goblins in my life, | " That on the supervise, no leisure bated, | " No not to stay the grinding of the ax, | My head should be strook off.

Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting, | That would not let me sleep; | and that should learn us, | There's a divinity that shapes our ends, | Rough hew them how we will. | Hora. That is most certain. | Ham. Up from my Cabbin, | My Sea-gown wrapt about me, in the dark | I grop'd to find out them; had my desire, | Reach'd their packet, and in fine withdrew | To mine own room again; making so bold | (My fears forgetting manners) to unseal | Their grand Commission; where I found, Horatio, | An exact command, that soon, as I to England came,| My head should be strook off. | Hora. Is't possible; | Ham. Here's the Commission, read it at more leisure: | But wilt thou hear now how I did proceed? | Hora. I beseech you.
